newsitem.title: USA: Ameritech, IBM begin Internet access trial.
newsitem.headline: Ameritech, IBM begin Internet access trial.

text.p: Ameritech Corp and International Business Machines Corp said Wednesday they will begin a customer trial next month of technology that could provide faster access to the Internet and other multimedia and data services.
The trial will involve approximately 200 Chicago-area customers of Ameritech and the IBM Global Network. It is based on technology known as Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line (ADSL).
ADSL technology will allow customers to interact with data networks and the Internet at speeds more than 50 times faster than an ordinary telephone line, the companies said.
The technology utilizes a portion of the existing phone line, allowing a customer to use the data portion of the line and talk on the voice portion of the line simultaneously.

During the six-month initial trial, customers will be provided a data access service that will allow them to receive or download information at speeds of up to 1.5 megabits per second, the companies said.
Ameritech will use ADSL modem equipment from Westell Technologies Inc for the initial trial.
Trials testing ADSL use with other switching platforms, such as asynchronous transfer mode (ATM), will be conducted by Ameritech at a later time.
Tom Reiman, president of product management for Ameritech, said the companies hope to have a high-speed service available to customers as early as next summer.
The IBM Global Network is providing a range of Internet and intranet services, plus various network and data communications resources, to this customer trial.

"The high speed access that this technology promises could improve both our current suite of Internet and intranet services as well as enable a new generation of IBM Global Network services in the future," Roger Dudley, general manager, marketing and service management, IBM Global Network, said in a statement.
